insights.insight: With Chrome deprecation completing the cookie's death across all major browsers, the ad industry has no cross-ecosystem, deterministic purchase signal left — probabilistic inference is what remains, and brands are paying $5+ CPM for it.

DKIM-verified email receipts produce cryptographic proof of purchase — not intent, not inference — making each receipt signal structurally more valuable than anything a data broker or DSP currently sells.

Google sees search intent, Visa sees a merchant category code, Apple sees app spend — none see across all three simultaneously, and none capture product-level detail; the receipt layer is the only data source that does.

Unlike Fetch or Ibotta, which hold identity-attached purchase data and carry GDPR/CCPA liability, this protocol's identity-free design means brands can query verified purchase signals without triggering consent or data-sharing obligations.

Zero brand queries have been executed against 3,430 verified receipts and $198K in confirmed GMV — the commerce intelligence layer exists but has not been commercially activated, meaning current pricing reflects pre-revenue data accumulation.

Ibotta IPO'd at $2.7B and Fetch raised $240M on identity-attached, single-ecosystem receipt data — the open, cross-ecosystem, identity-free version of the same asset class has no comparable market price yet.
